instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.P3V3S5_PGOOD: What is P3V3S5_PGOOD? P3V3S5_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP3V3_S5 power rail is working..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>


Had powered USB device inserted, now does not turn on. No liquid damage, no burnt components that i can see
green light present, goes to orange.
CPU stays cold, PCH <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> gets warm.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.34v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.38v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.36v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.13v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.12v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> 1.797v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0.04v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0.04v
pin1 0.741v
pin3 0.093v
pin4 0.04v
pin5 0.7v
pin6 0.131v
pin7 0.77v

CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD= 0.05v

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> 
CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD= 0.05v
pin13/14 = 5.1v
pin3 = 3.2v
pin10=1.05v


<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<RESISTOR>R2810</RESISTOR> - pin1 3.3v pin 2 0v (measures fine at 10k)

<TRANSISTOR>Q2810</TRANSISTOR>

pin 5 <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
pin 2 & 3 = 5v


So i am missing:

CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>


Wen to go look back at USB looked at <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>

VCC 3.3v

<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>
pins 3 & 2 = 5v
pin4 = 3.3v
pin5 = 0v
pin7= 0v
pin8 (unconnected but)=0.5v
pin9= 0v
pin10= 3.3v

The fact the PCH is getting warm makes me think it is dead / shorted, but i can't see any burnt or damaged components. 
I've failed in trying to work out which one of the missing rails should come first. I suspect that <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is the big problem.
Would appreciate any suggestions before moving on ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message:
The system is trying to get into S0 and already partially is in a S0 state, there is no surprise the PCH is getting warmish.

You are probably missing a power line, check why <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is not there:
Voltage of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_VMON</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_VMON</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>VMON_3V3_DIV</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_VMON</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_VMON</SIGNAL>?
<RESISTOR>R7953</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7956</RESISTOR> within resistor specification?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message: There is a rail missing and it is not  <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> cause that one is not in the PGOOD sequence. Voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> are ok so <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is pulled down by <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>-66 and friends in that area. Measure voltages on both sides of them.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message:
Thank you for your replies.


<RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR> 
pin1 <SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0.17V
PIN2 <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  = 0.05V
MEASURES 99OHM

<RESISTOR>R7964</RESISTOR>
PINS 1& 2 0.05V
CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD=0.05V
MEASURES 99OHM

<RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR>
PIN1 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL>=0.05V
PIN2 <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0.05V
MEASURES 100OHM

<RESISTOR>R7966</RESISTOR>
PINS 1& 2 0.05V (<SIGNAL>P1V8SO_PGOOD</SIGNAL>)
MEASURES 99OHM

<RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>
PIN1 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>=3.3V
PIN2= 0.05V
MEASURES 2.1KOHM (UNDER BUT NOT A PROBLEM)

<RESISTOR>R7901</RESISTOR>
PIN1 & 2 0.05V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0.05V
MEASURES 77OHM


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_VMON</SIGNAL> MEASURED AT PIN 1 <RESISTOR>R7956</RESISTOR> 3.3V, PIN 2 0.131V
MEASURES 149KOHM


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_VMON</SIGNAL> MEASURED AT PIN 1 <RESISTOR>R7951</RESISTOR> 3.3V PIN 2 0.766V
MEASURES 8,8K (SUM OF DIVDER I BELIVE)

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_VMON</SIGNAL> MEASURED AT PIN1 <RESISTOR>R7955</RESISTOR> 1.34V PIN 2 0.774V
MEASURES 990OHM

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_VMON</SIGNAL> MEASURED AT PIN 1 <RESISTOR>R7955</RESISTOR> 1.1V PIN 2  0.79
MEASURES 1KOHM

SO I AM MISSING 

<SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL>


TRYING TO FIND <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> FIRST WE DO HAVE <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> AT 3.4V

LOOKING <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>
PIN20 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 0.05V
PIN21 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> 3.4V
PIN12 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_REG_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4V
THIS HAS ENABLES, AND <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> IS PRESENT SO GOING TO LOOK AT THE OTHERS


<SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> 
PIN14 0V.
PIN19 = 5.12V
PIN20 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>) = 5.12V
PIN15 (en)=3.2V
PIN14=0.017V
PIN12=0V

<CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> (PIN11) DOSEN'T LOOK RIGHT SO REPLACING.
DIDN'T CHANGE ANYTHING
<RESISTOR>R7141</RESISTOR> & 7142 BOTH MEASURE 1KOHM
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> HAS POWER, AND ENABLE PUT IS NOT TURNING ON. 
IT LOOKS FINE. 


<SIGNAL>P1V8S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
(<SIGNAL>P1V8_S0</SIGNAL> is present)
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
PINS1,2,3 = 3.3V
PIN5(EN) = 3.3V
PIN7 = 0.05V

Once again, has power, has enable but is not putting out PGOOD.

is it worth pulling <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7964</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR> to see if one rail is pulling them all down?
Thanks for any help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message:
TLDR. 

There must be a voltage drop on <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>-66. The <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> side will be lower than the PGOOD signal side. This will be the one pulling the rest down. Voltage drop will only be a 50mV or so, so measure carefully. No need to pull them all.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and others.
threads.message:
Sorry for the long previous post.
You were correct as usual duke. <SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL> was the problem and pulling the others down.
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> looked fine, had enables and voltage but was not turning on.

Replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> (and USB chip). Machine now working fine. Thank you may mark as closed.
